articles.title: Catherine joined by stars and charity heroes for Christmas carol concert
articles.summary: Actors Kate Winslet and Chiwetel Ejiofor were among the 1,600 guests at Westminster Abbey.
articles.content:
Catherine joined by stars and charity heroes for Christmas carol concert

12 hours ago Share Save Sean Coughlan Royal correspondent, Westminster Abbey Share Save

PA Media

The Princess of Wales has hosted her annual Christmas carol concert at Westminster Abbey, with guests including royals, celebrities and local heroes who have helped their communities. In a festive Abbey, dotted with Christmas trees, the 1,600 guests heard a mix of traditional carols, music and poems from actors such as Kate Winslet and Chiwetel Ejiofor - and a Bible reading from the pulpit by Prince William. The theme of the service, held in the candle-lit Abbey, was kindness and showing love to others. Among the guests were Anna and Jonathan Cordiner, whose daughter died of a brain tumour, and who set up a charity, Kayleigh's Wee Stars, to support families who have a child with a terminal illness.

Prince William, and the couple's children George, Charlotte and Louis, were greeted by Catherine outside the Abbey ahead of the service. Wearing a long green Christmassy coat, Catherine met members of the congregation inside the Abbey, speaking to Holocaust survivor Steven Frank, as well as singer Katie Melua and actor Eugene Levy, who recently interviewed William in what was one of the most open discussions we've seen with the prince. Catherine chatted to Dame Mary Berry, who had helped to make the Christmas wreaths that decorated the medieval Abbey. The message of this year's concert was that in a fragmented and disconnected world, small acts of generosity and love can bring people and communities together. "The time, care and compassion you give, often quietly and unspoken, and without any expectation or recognition, make an extraordinary difference to the lives of others," wrote Catherine, in a letter ahead of the carol service.

Reuters PA Catherine met actors Joe Locke, Kate Winslet and Chiwetel Ejiofor, and composer Paul Gladstone Reid Canadian actor Eugene Levy, who recently interviewed Prince William at Windsor Castle

The princess has been making her own gradual return to public life after her cancer diagnosis and chemotherapy, last month delivering her first public speech for two years, in which she talked about recognising the "quiet, often invisible work of caring". The order of service, with its green ivy design, reflected an interest of Catherine's, with the quote "Love is enough" from the poetry of William Morris, the Victorian designer and social activist. The princess had admired Morris's work on a visit to the V&A East Storehouse. Guests arriving at the Abbey were entertained by young musicians supported by the Future Talent charity, co-founded by the Duchess of Kent to widen access to music lessons. The duchess, who died in September, had been a primary school music teacher and a great supporter of giving more young people opportunities to play music.

Carys Wood, aged 18, who plays the trumpet and is from Pembrokeshire, has been assisted by the charity, with grants helping towards musical instruments, lessons and travel costs - and she said it was "awesome" to be playing at the Westminster Abbey service. "Music can be very expensive," Carys said. She is now studying at the Royal Academy of Music, and added that "everyone should have the opportunity" to develop their musical skills. When Carys found out about how the duchess had supported music, she said: "I was amazed by what she'd done and that she'd worked as a teacher."

Reuters

It highlights real-world positive impact on communities and individuals, with a broad inspirational message about generosity and love, supported by notable public figures and charity efforts. The story is focused, detailed, and uplifting, though its impact is more societal and cultural than in traditional categories like Health or Environment.

articles.title: EU reform plan: financial markets are to become more attractive
articles.summary: The EU Commission wants to simplify financial market rules with a new reform package and shift more supervisory powers to Paris. Will private investors also benefit?
articles.content:
The EU Commission wants to simplify financial market rules with a new reform package and shift more supervisory powers to Paris. Will private investors also benefit?

Brussels (dpa) – The complex financial market rules in Germany and the other EU member states are to be fundamentally streamlined and modernized according to the wishes of the European Commission. A reform package presented in Brussels to increase competitiveness envisages harmonizing regulations for trading venues and streamlining supervisory processes.

For example, supervisory powers over significant cross-border actors are to be transferred to the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) in Paris. These would include, for instance, certain trading venues, all providers of crypto services and central securities depositories. The latter are responsible for the custody and transfer of securities.

Ten trillion euros in savings

The aim of the planned reforms is to create the conditions for a globally attractive financial market. Citizens are also to receive cheaper and better access to investment opportunities throughout the EU. This is of crucial importance, the EU Commission argues, as private individuals currently have around 10 trillion euros of their savings in bank accounts. These deposits are safe, but often generate low returns compared to investments in securities.

The responsible EU Commissioner Maria Luís Albuquerque said in Brussels that by building a genuine single financial market, people would be offered better opportunities to grow their wealth. Europe had tolerated a fragmentation that slowed down the economy for too long.

Decision lies with Parliament and member states

The proposals of the EU Commission will now be discussed by the European Parliament and the Council of the member states. The Commission hopes that they can then be adopted and implemented.

Initial reactions from members of parliament were predominantly positive. The economic and financial policy spokesperson of the European People’s Party group, Markus Ferber, described the package as an opportunity to take a big step forward. “Compared to the USA, our capital markets are fragmented, small and illiquid – this harms growth, innovation and competitiveness in Europe every day,” said the parliamentarian. The German MEP Rasmus Andresen from the Greens stated that Europe needs strong, central financial market supervision. That is why his group welcomes the Commission’s proposal to entrust ESMA directly with the supervision of key market actors. (4 December)
articles.reasoning: The EU Commission's reform plan aims to simplify and harmonize financial market regulations across member states, potentially creating a more attractive and competitive financial market. This could benefit private investors by providing cheaper and better access to investment opportunities, addressing the issue of low returns on savings. The reform has broad significance for the EU population and economy, with clear details on the proposed changes and expected benefits.
articles.personality_title: EU plans to simplify financial rules and boost investment opportunities
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The European Union has many different rules for financial markets in each member country. These rules can be complicated and make it hard for people and businesses to invest and trade across borders.

**What happened** – The EU Commission announced a plan to make financial market rules simpler and more similar across all member states. They want to give more power to the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) in Paris to supervise important parts of the market, like crypto services and places where securities are traded or stored. The goal is to make the financial market easier to use and more attractive.

**Impact** – This plan could help people in the EU have better and cheaper access to investment options. Right now, many people keep their savings in bank accounts where the money is safe but grows very slowly. With easier access to investments, they might earn more from their savings. The reform also aims to make Europe’s financial market stronger and more competitive compared to places like the USA.

**What's next step** – The EU Parliament and member countries will now discuss the plan. If they agree, the changes will be put into action. Some members of the European Parliament have already said they like the idea and see it as a way to help Europe’s economy grow.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The EU is working to simplify financial rules and improve investment chances for people across Europe by giving more power to a central authority and creating a more unified market.
articles.personality_title_fr: L'UE veut simplifier les règles financières et faciliter l'investissement
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – L'Union européenne a des règles financières différentes dans chaque pays membre, ce qui rend les investissements compliqués.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – La Commission européenne a présenté un plan pour rendre ces règles plus simples et similaires partout. Elle veut donner plus de pouvoir à l'Autorité européenne des marchés financiers (ESMA) à Paris pour surveiller des parties importantes du marché comme les services crypto et les lieux d'échange de titres.

**Impact** – Ce plan pourrait permettre aux citoyens européens d'accéder plus facilement et à moindre coût à des options d'investissement. Actuellement, beaucoup gardent leur argent en banque où il rapporte peu. Avec ces changements, ils pourraient mieux faire fructifier leur argent. Cela rendrait aussi le marché financier européen plus fort et compétitif.

**Prochaine étape** – Le Parlement européen et les pays membres vont maintenant discuter du projet. S'ils l'acceptent, les changements seront appliqués. Certains députés européens apprécient déjà cette idée pour stimuler l'économie.

**En une phrase** – L'UE travaille à simplifier les règles financières et à améliorer les possibilités d'investissement en renforçant une autorité centrale et en unifiant le marché.
articles.personality_title_es: La UE plane simplificar las reglas financieras y mejorar las inversiones
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La Unión Europea tiene reglas financieras diferentes en cada país miembro, lo que dificulta las inversiones y el comercio entre países.

**Qué pasó** – La Comisión Europea presentó un plan para hacer que estas reglas sean más simples y parecidas en toda la UE. Quieren dar más poder a la Autoridad Europea de Valores y Mercados (ESMA) en París para supervisar partes importantes del mercado, como los servicios de criptomonedas y los lugares donde se negocian o guardan valores.

**Impacto** – Este plan podría ayudar a las personas a tener acceso más barato y fácil a opciones de inversión. Ahora, mucha gente guarda su dinero en bancos donde crece muy poco. Con estas mejoras, podrían ganar más con sus ahorros. También busca hacer que el mercado financiero europeo sea más fuerte y competitivo.

**Próximo paso** – El Parlamento Europeo y los países miembros discutirán el plan. Si lo aprueban, se pondrá en marcha. Algunos parlamentarios ya dicen que les gusta y que puede ayudar a la economía de Europa.

**Frase clave** – La UE quiere simplificar las reglas financieras y ofrecer mejores oportunidades de inversión al fortalecer una autoridad central y unificar el mercado.
